moves.1. b3: Larsen scored some fine victories with this opening named Nimzowitsch-Larsen attack.
moves.1... e5: White allows Black to occupy the centre which is hyper-modern opening.
moves.2. Bb2: White starts his attack against Black's centre.
moves.2... Nc6 3. c4: Theory suggests 3. e3 d5 followed by 4. Bb5 pinning the knight.
moves.3... Nf6 4. Nf3: 4. Nf3 probably inviting the e5 pawn to advance to e4.
moves.4... e4 5. Nd4 Bc5: Black's is ahead in development and is ready to castle.
moves.6. Nxc6 dxc6: White saddles Black with doubled pawns on c-file. Now the e-pawn will be attacked. A typical hyper modern opening. White exchanged his developed knight and is behind in development.
moves.7. e3 Bf5 8. Qc2 Qe7: The play revolves around the e4 pawn.
moves.9. Be2: 9. d4 would have captured the centre for White.
moves.9... O-O-O: Black castles on the queen side to avoid an attack by the long range White bishop on b2.
moves.10. f4: White's opening strategy seems to be clear. His bishop on b2 is being supported by a strong pawn chain. Black cannot capture the f-pawn by en passant as the bishop is on f4.
moves.10... Ng4: Black attacks the f2 square with his knight. Looks like a typical amateur play but Spassky was the World champion in 1970.
moves.12. h3: White tries to drive away the pesky knight.
moves.12... h4: !! Black offers the knight. Spassky has devised a brilliant maneuvre to take advantage of the White king in the centre.
moves.13. hxg4: Larsen, an aggressive player himself, spent 45 minutes before accepting the knight and probably could not see the maneuver planned by Spassky.
moves.13... hxg3 14. Rg1 Rh1: !!! This is the move which won the brilliancy prize. A second piece being offered. Can we see any attack after this?
moves.15. Rxh1 g2: A tiny pawn is sufficient to bring White's game down.
moves.16. Rf1: Larsen hopes for gxf1 but Spassky did not sac 2 pieces for nothing. 16. Rg1 may have been better but Larsen must have lost his cool by Spassky's audacious sacrifices.
moves.16... Qh4+ 17. Kd1 gxf1=Q+: Larsen resigns as White is mated in 3 moves. Can we see the mate at least now? It is amazing that Larsen, a top flight grandmaster playing on top board, for World team should have collapsed in his own opening. So it is Ok if we lose our games in similar fashion, eh?
